results.title: Kyara
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Hank Kerr
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop Telling Tales. Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for Telling Tales.
This film is a message from Hank Kerr to his daughter, Kyara. It speaks about his alcoholism and determination to become a better person for the sake of his daughter. Kerr also talks about the jobs he has had including as a clown in the first Aboriginal Clown troop called the Oogadee Boogadees.

results.title: To do or not to do.....
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Jock Noble
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Jock Noble, CEO of Diversity@work Australia, talks about the impact having Polio had on his childhood and how that has subsequently shaped his career in helping companies to strengthen through diversity in their workforce.

results.title: Why?
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Tehree Gordon
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Tehree says she is an ordinary Australian, though she was a recipient of the Senior Australian of the Year Award in 2004. In this story, Tehree talks about her passion for wildlife from an early age leading to her founding Jirrahlinga Koala and Wildlife Sanctuary with her partner Hamish. The sanctuary has provided work opportunities and enrichment to people living with disabilities and the elderly.

results.title: Doors Will Open
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Rajani Shrestha
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Rajani Shrestha moved to Melbourne from Nepal in 1992 with her husband and son. Rajani recounts the struggle she faced to find meaningful work in a new country. She tells of her journey which eventually led to her working at AMES Australia.

results.title: My Banquet...
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Chey Scovell
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Chey Scovell recounts his childhood growing up as an Australian born in Malaysia and the last four years of schooling spent in Papua New Guinea. He tells of the culture shock he experienced when returning back to Australia.

results.title: What Do We Want?
results.creator_credit: Molly O'Connor, Philippa Campey, Film Camp and Reko Rennie
results.credit_line:
2022
Reko Rennie, Kamilaroi
Three-channel video
Commissioned by ACMI and Artbank
results.brief_description: What Do We Want draws on 1970s Blaxploitation films and Rennie’s own martial arts practice to explore political, environmental and social questions through an Aboriginal Australian lens.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Molly O’Connor, Philippa Campey, Film Camp and Reko Rennie
results.description:
An army of First Nations warriors come out to play in this latest action-packed video by Kamilaroi artist Reko Rennie.

An all-Indigenous crew of martial arts students train together in their dojo; learning teachings of discipline, self-defense and teamwork. When the Sensei cries, “What do we want?” the students respond, “Restitution! Land back! Equality! No more cops killing our mob!”, vocalising demands of environmental, political and social concern, and reflecting the broad diversity within contemporary Indigenous urban society.

Rennie was taught martial arts by his father while growing up in Melbourne’s inner West. What Do We Want? marries his 25-year history of martial arts and his arts practice, while expanding Rennie’s evolving moving image repertoire into the realm of performance.

What Do We Want? takes influence from martial arts films including Blaxploitation films of the 1970s and 80s; utilising the medium to make a statement about authenticity, respect, bravery and collective power. The students in What Do We Want? become a force to be reckoned with.

Displayed in the gallery in a massive three-channel video installation, the work loudly and proudly conveys the diversity of First Nations peoples, and the ongoing fight for justice that unifies them, raising urgent questions that require action and response.

Acknowledgements

Director: Reko Rennie

Produced by Film Camp, Philippa Campey, Molly O’Connor

Original composition by A.B. Original

Produced by Trials

Director of Photography: Sherwin Akbarzadeh

Editor: Carlo Zeccola

Featuring

Sensei Master: Adam Briggs (Yorta Yorta)

Students: Caine Muir (Yorta Yorta and Wati Wati), Inala Cooper (Yawuru), James Saunders (Gundtijmara and Wiradjuri), Joe Bell (Yorta Yorta), Kelvin Onus King (Gunditjmara), Kimmie Lovegrove (Ngarrindjeri), Mila Rennie Galvin (Kamilaroi/Gamilaroi/Gamilaraay),Reko Rennie (Kamilaroi/Gamilaroi/Gamilaraay), Sermsah Pepi Bin Saad (Nyikina), Shane Mankitya Cook (Guwa (Koa) and Wulli Wulli), Talahiva Rose (Gomeroi), Vicky Frowd (Wiradjuri)

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 17]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents a glimpse of a somewhat nostalgic version of Australian suburban family life as it was in the 50s and early 60s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:07:00 children playing with sprinkler and toys 1950s
00:02:19:00 leaving hospital with baby
00:03:39:00 a 1950s Christmas scene; children with toys
00:04:59:00 brief shot of Queenscliff with kids riding in Cobb & Co. horse-drawn carriage
00:06:53:00 girl jumping on a trampoline with pier in the background – trampoline park with interesting “trampolines” sign
00:08:59:00 nice shot of toddler waddling towards the camera
00:12:54:00 backyard children’s birthday party
00:17:05:00 young girl using a hula hoop in a paddock
00:18:02:00 toddler gets a home haircut

results.title: Time changes
results.brief_description: “Time changes” is an experimental, self-reflexive film, comprised of footage filmed over four years by Sue Ford and her friends. Described by the artist as being “a documentary about time and change, focusing on four men who were filmmakers and close friends”, the film features friends Stuart Green, Chris Maudson, John Phillips and Paul Reed, as well as Ford, her children Emma and Ben, and artists Richard Brennan, Bonita Ely, Margo Nash and Ashe Venn. Through unscripted dialogue, the friends’ conversations range across topics such as the integrity of filmmaking and creative practice to ways of living and relationships.

group_siblings.title: Egami

production_dates.notes: Previously catalogued as 1977, updated to 1978 following research by Julia Murphy 6 Apr 2022

results.title: Woman in a house
results.brief_description: One of Sue Ford’s earliest films, “Woman in a house” is a feminist critique of domestic female roles. In this short film, a young woman in a suburban house escapes the confinement of her life through surreal dream sequences created with experimental montage techniques. Made in 1972, the film was shown at screenings run by the Melbourne Filmmaker’s Co-op and was one of the most popular films available to rent from the feminist film collective Reel Women, of which Ford was a founding member, in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

results.title: Sue Ford Moving Image Collection
results.brief_description:
The Sue Ford Moving Image Collection contains the film and video work of Australian artist Sue Ford (1943–2009). The collection includes complete films made during the 1970s and 1980s, including “Faces”, “Time changes” and “Egami”, as well as an extensive archive of 8mm home movies, documentary footage, offcuts, and process-based experiments.

Sue Ford is one of Australia’s pre-eminent photographers and experimental filmmakers. Establishing her photographic practice in the late 1960s, she was the first woman photographer to hold a solo exhibition at the National Gallery of Victoria in 1974. She was a key figure in Melbourne’s art scene throughout the 1970s, where she was involved with the Women’s Art Group alongside artists such as Bonita Ely and Micky Allan. After a time spent in Sydney where she was involved with the Sydney Filmmakers Cooperative, she became a founding member of the feminist film collective Reel Women in the late 1970s.

Most of her films were created during this period and she continued to make photographic and multimedia work throughout the 1990s and 2000s. Her work is held in the collection of the National Gallery of Victoria, the Art Gallery of New South Wales, the Art Gallery of Western Australia, and the National Gallery of Australia.

The Sue Ford Moving Image Collection has been generously donated to ACMI by the Sue Ford Archive, co-directed by her son, Ben Ford, and friend, Joy Hirst.
